categories.title: Hyperfy Development Updates and Community Discussions

content.text: Recent Hyperfy community discussions have focused on technical improvements, feature requests, and onboarding strategies for both developers and non-technical users. Key topics included physics synchronization, authentication, media optimization, AI integration, and app communication.

A major technical issue discussed was the jitter caused by syncing rigidbody and controller positions in FixedUpdate. The solution involved separating client-side rigidbody logic from server-side controller logic and using tags with overlapSphere for detection. However, limitations in PhysX’s PxCapsuleController restrict adding tags or contact support.

Authentication challenges were addressed, particularly iframe limitations that prevent wallet connections in-world. A proposed solution is to build a mod for hypkg to enable in-world authentication, allowing direct player ID to wallet mapping.

A bug was identified where unlinked materials still behaved as linked due to the order of operations when unlinking mesh and accessing material. This issue is under investigation, and a fix is planned.

Snap points were clarified as positional guides without parent-child relationships. Workarounds using triggers and tags were suggested to simulate such behavior. A feature request was made to improve this system.

Agentic workflows were proposed to enable in-world script validation using context, memory, and feedback cycles. This would require improved inter-app communication and database interaction, which are currently limited.
App traversal has been enhanced with the addition of a children array to all nodes, enabling full traversal. Documentation and examples are needed to support this feature.

Media performance optimization was discussed, especially for GIFs in Hyperfy v1. Converting large GIFs to MP4 is recommended for better performance, particularly on VR and mobile. Hyperfy v2 offers improved media handling.

Non-technical users were encouraged to build games in Hyperfy v2 using AI. Starting points include app.configure and referencing existing hyps. Even basic AI models like Qwen are sufficient for prototyping.
For AI-powered voice applications, LiveKit was recommended as an alternative to Twilio, with future integration planned in Hyperfy v2. FlowiseAI was suggested for SMS workflows.
A roadmap update confirmed upcoming PvPvE features, a DAO, and a potential marketplace. Community members were invited to contribute featured apps and improve social media engagement.

categories.title: Hyperfy Development: Technical Updates, Tools, and Ecosystem Enhancements

content.text: Recent discussions in the Hyperfy community have focused on a range of technical improvements, feature requests, and ecosystem tools. Key topics included physics synchronization, authentication, media optimization, AI integration, and asset packaging.

Physics and controller synchronization issues were addressed by separating rigidbody (client-side) and controller (server-side) logic, using tags and overlapSphere for detection. Limitations in PhysX’s PxCapsuleController were noted, particularly its lack of tag/contact support.

Authentication challenges due to iframe limitations were discussed. A proposed solution involves building a mod for hypkg to enable in-world wallet authentication, allowing direct player ID-to-wallet mapping without relying on external iframes.

A bug was identified where unlinked materials still behaved as linked. The issue appears to stem from the order of operations when unlinking mesh and accessing material properties. Further testing is needed to confirm the bug.

The community is working on improving app deactivation, snap point behavior, and inter-app communication. Snap points currently act as positional guides without parent-child relationships, but workarounds using triggers and tags were suggested.

Agentic workflows are being explored, with a roadmap proposed to support context, memory, feedback cycles, and in-world script validation. Enhancements to inter-app communication and database interaction are also under consideration.

The Modular Context Protocol (MCP) was introduced as a standardized API layer to simplify AI agent integration. MCP abstracts service interfaces and formats requests/responses automatically, enabling agents to interact with APIs, file systems, and databases more efficiently.

FastMCP, a tool built on MCP, allows developers to define tools and endpoints with minimal boilerplate. It supports interoperability across services and reduces token and compute costs by providing agents with instant context access.

Media performance optimization was discussed, particularly the poor performance of GIFs in Hyperfy v1. Converting GIFs to MP4 is recommended for better performance, especially on VR and mobile. Hyperfy v2 offers improved media handling.

AI integration for non-technical users was explored. Users were encouraged to use app.configure and reference nodes, with examples from existing hyps. Even basic AI models like Qwen are sufficient for building simple games or experiences.
LiveKit was recommended as an alternative to Twilio for voice, video, and screen sharing, and will be integrated into Hyperfy v2. FlowiseAI was suggested for SMS integration in AI workflows.

Asset packaging strategies were discussed, particularly combining multiple GLB files into a single .hyp file. A scripting approach using a parent object was recommended. Native support for asset collections is in development for the HyperWorld marketplace.
